posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91388546
I'd recommend anons to experiment with the way they think about prompts.
Instead of:
fisheye lens image, woman, summer dress, beach
Try writing something like:
highly detailed fisheye lens drawing of a blonde woman wearing a summer hat and wearing a summer dress on the beach, colorful
(I didn't test these but you get the idea). Models are usually trained by providing sentences describing the images, not by mindlessly tagging them with a million different (often slightly contradictory) tags. And the base for every model, even anime ones, was trained like that. And don't lean too much on the prompts posted by anons or civitai users. Just because their pictures are beautiful doesn't always mean they knew what they were doing. Especially on civitai, you can often see their image ignored half of the prompt (because, and this is another issue for another rant entirely, most models have CLIP problems).
Don't make your prompts too elaborate, don't abuse the negative prompt field and learn how prompts ACTUALLY work on your model. This is not some magical black box. Educate yourself:

https://strikingloo.github.io/stable-diffusion-vs-dalle-2

https://docs.google.com/document/d/17VPu3U2qXthOpt2zWczFvf-AH6z37hxUbvEe1rJTsEc/edit

https://sweet-hall-e72.notion.site/A-Traveler-s-Guide-to-the-Latent-Space-85efba7e5e6a40e5bd3cae980f30235f

I think I'm going to leave these threads and continue my SD adventure solo. It's been fun bros. Thank you.

I tested a set of 4400mhz vs 3200mhz DDR4 in a variety of settings and actually got worse performance out of the 4400 set because of the slightly slower timings (19CL vs 16CL)

DDR5 is really hampered by its sloppy timings in a lot of use-cases currently. Yeah, they've doubled the frequency, but they've doubled the timings too. If your workload could benefit from more memory I would definitely choose that, the frequency improvement may not benefit you at all.

For a while I was getting crashes randomly for instance just sitting idle or web browsing. But then I thought I had solved it by setting the power settings in Nvidia control panel, however I then started to get crashes with high GPU utilization (I had the Witcher 3 running with rt ultra settings and GPU utilization at 96%). But it's been extremely difficult to troubleshoot this because I was playing the game for hours yesterday with the single 16-pin cable without a single issue (but it would usually crash shortly after quitting the game).

>The A1000G has two 12vhpwr cables. If the 16 pin to 16 pin gave you crashes, try the other one (2x8 to 16?).
The other cable that connects to the 12vhpwr port on the PSU is just a 2x pcie cable. I actually used it to connect to the Nvidia adapter (along with two separate pcie connections).

And for other weird power issues with the 12vhpwr, prior to using the Nvidia adapter I had a 64 GB RAM kit that seemed to trigger the crashes much more often. The GPU would crash without fail less than 10 minutes after booting (whereas the other 32 GB kit I have was more random). But now while using the Nvidia adapter on the 4090 I can use the 64 GB RAM without any issues at all so far.

posts.com: What use flags should i emerge librewolf with? Short explanations of them on the wiki aren't clear enough for me

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91371122
When emerging the librewolf browser, the following use flags are commonly recommended:

gtk3: Enables support for the GTK+ 3 graphical toolkit, which provides the user interface for the browser.

pulseaudio: Enables support for the PulseAudio sound server, which allows the browser to play audio.

wayland: Enables support for the Wayland display server protocol, which is used for graphical applications on modern Linux systems.

dbus: Enables support for the D-Bus inter-process communication system, which is used for communication between different applications.

alsa: Enables support for the ALSA (Advanced Linux Sound Architecture) sound system, which provides audio support for Linux

You can choose to use the ALSA or PulseAudio use flags even if you are using PipeWire as your sound server. However, it depends on whether the librewolf browser requires ALSA or PulseAudio specifically, or if it can use either one. If the browser can use either one, then you can choose not to enable the ALSA or PulseAudio use flag, since you are using PipeWire as your sound server.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91371543
No, there is no standard LC_COLLATE value for sorting Latin and Cyrillic characters based on their phonetic value. The LC_COLLATE value determines the collation order, or sorting order, of characters in the locale, which is typically based on the alphabetical order of the characters in the language used in the locale.

If you need to sort characters based on their phonetic value, you may need to write a custom sorting function or use a library that implements a custom collation algorithm that takes the phonetic value of characters into account.

Note that sorting based on phonetic value is not a common requirement, and sorting based on the alphabetical order of characters is more widely used and well supported.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91378880
When you install Windows, you're extremely limited with how that installation is handled. You basically point Windows to one drive or partition, and can only say, "Ok, use all of that".
On Linux, you can configure where different parts of the system reside physically on your storage devices. As in you can choose which system directories reside on which hard drive, or what mount point goes to what device.
/home contains user preferences in directories like /home/user/.config, as well as a lot of other personal files since it's where your pictures/videos/music are. It's similar to the Users folder on a Windows computer.

When I reinstalled, I formatted the partition I'm using for my / directory which includes all of my system files, applications, kernel, etc - but I didn't format my /home partition. I just told the new Linux installer "hey, mount this same partition to /home" but didn't overwrite it.
So now on the new system, all of the newly installed applications look at that /home directory and see my config files, and immediately use them without me needing to set them up again myself.

How can I prevent my system from hanging on shutdown? The hang only happens when I lose connection to a mounted smb/nfs share. I tried googling but I got shit for results aside from changing "DefaultTimeoutStopSec" in /etc/systemd/system.conf. I'm not confident that will solve the issue though as that answer was for an issue that had nothing to do with losing connection to a network share.
pic not related

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91385264
Add a unit file that runs 
umount -f -l /path/to/mount/point
before shutdown. That "loosly" unmounts the filesystem rather than Systemd unmounting it and waiting forever until the network comes back so that it can sync and unmount correctly (which might never happen).

>>91385389
You can ping the server. The problem you face is that you don't know if the server is up and any attempt to find out (ping isn't exactly accurate) will cause your script to block if it gets it wrong (it's the kernel executing the syscall that's blocking so you can't do anything about it. this is one of those shit things about Linux with no real "right way" to fix it).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91385512
As long as it's not hopeless I'll try and come up with something
>>91385674
>The problem you face is that you don't know if the server is up and any attempt to find out (ping isn't exactly accurate) will cause your script to block
True, I've got to imagine that I'm not the first person with this issue. Any pre-existing scripts that might be a good starting point?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91385854
Something like this would work:
host=192.168.x.x
mnt=/path/to/mount/point
if timeout 10 ping -c3 $host
then
    umount $mnt
else
    umount -f -l $mnt
fi

Basically unmount it normally if you can ping the server, otherwise lazily unmount it. There's no guarantee that the server is up just because you can ping it (it still might block and halt the shutdown) but it's better than nothing.

If you never want it to block you have to always 
umount -f -l
.

void interleaved_copy(int *to, int *from, int count) {
  int n = (count + 7) / 8;
  switch (count % 8) {
    case 0: do { *to++ = *from++;

            } while (--n > 0);

}

// generate a random float in [0.0, 1.0) from a random uint32_t
float random_uniform(void)
{
    uint32_t rand = random_u32();

    union {
        float f32;
        uint32_t u32;
    } conv = {
        .u32 = (rand >> 9) | 0x3f800000
    };

    return conv.f32 - 1.0f;
}

#include <inttypes.h>
#include <stdint.h>
#include <stdio.h>

#define BIN_CHAR(cc) ((uint8_t)((cc) - '0'))

#define BIN_2(bits_str) (BIN_CHAR((bits_str)[0]) << 0)
#define BIN_3(bits_str) ((BIN_CHAR((bits_str)[0]) << 1) | BIN_2(&((bits_str)[1])))
#define BIN_4(bits_str) ((BIN_CHAR((bits_str)[0]) << 2) | BIN_3(&((bits_str)[1])))
#define BIN_5(bits_str) ((BIN_CHAR((bits_str)[0]) << 3) | BIN_4(&((bits_str)[1])))
#define BIN_6(bits_str) ((BIN_CHAR((bits_str)[0]) << 4) | BIN_5(&((bits_str)[1])))
#define BIN_7(bits_str) ((BIN_CHAR((bits_str)[0]) << 5) | BIN_6(&((bits_str)[1])))
#define BIN_8(bits_str) ((BIN_CHAR((bits_str)[0]) << 6) | BIN_7(&((bits_str)[1])))
#define BIN_9(bits_str) ((BIN_CHAR((bits_str)[0]) << 7) | BIN_8(&((bits_str)[1])))

#define BIN_(bits_str) \
    sizeof(bits_str) == 2 ? BIN_2(bits_str) : \
    sizeof(bits_str) == 3 ? BIN_3(bits_str) : \
    sizeof(bits_str) == 4 ? BIN_4(bits_str) : \
    sizeof(bits_str) == 5 ? BIN_5(bits_str) : \
    sizeof(bits_str) == 6 ? BIN_6(bits_str) : \
    sizeof(bits_str) == 7 ? BIN_7(bits_str) : \
    sizeof(bits_str) == 8 ? BIN_8(bits_str) : \
    sizeof(bits_str) == 9 ? BIN_9(bits_str) : 0
#define b(bits) BIN_(#bits)

posts.com:
A neat side effect of function macro expansion is that the preprocessor won't expand function macro names if they don't have arguments which lets you use a macro function that is the same name as a type to act as a sort of constructor, this can let you work around C not letting you define a function with the same name as a type for example. Useful for getting some nicer syntax. Also you can do argument count overloading for macros so that they expand to different functions depending on the number of arguments.

#define OVERLOAD(IGNORE1, IGNORE2, IGNORE3, INGORE4, IGNORE5, IGNORE6, IGNORE7, NAME, ...) NAME

#define VEC4_XYZW(x_, y_, z_, w_) ((vec4){.x = x_, .y = y_, .z = z_, .w = w_})
#define VEC4_SET(t_) ((vec4){.x = t_, .y = t_, .z = t_, .w = t_})
#define vec4(x, ...) OVERLOAD(__VA_ARGS__, _, _, _, _, VEC4_XYZW, _, _, VEC2_SET)((x), __VA_ARGS__)

vec4 v = vec4(1, 2, 3, 4); // v = <1, 2, 3, 4>
// or
vec4 v = vec4(1); // v = <1, 1, 1, 1>

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Tree packing, basically trying to use as little memory as possible per node since the tree structure is large. A leaf node stores an index (46 bits) and a length (32 bits) that is used to lookup elements in a contiguous array. The float for internal nodes is overlapped with the uint32 since they are mutually exclusive, similarly the index of the left node is overlapped with objIndex since it is also mutually exclusive. 2 bits are used to identify the node as either a leaf node, or one of 3 types of internal nodes. The right child of an internal node is adjacent in memory to the parent node so you don't need to store its index, this is done by creating the parent, then the right node, then the left node recursively in a contiguous container. If you have a pointer to the parent you can do 
parent + 1
to get the right child or do 
(KDNode*)parent->right
(although this probably violates strict aliasing). Each node is 10 bytes, you can shrink it down further but I needed larger than 32 bit indices.

#pragma pack(push, 1)

typedef struct {
    union {
        struct {
            u64 len : 32;
            u64     : 32;
            u16     : 16;
        };

        struct {
            u16          : 16;
            u64          : 16;
            u64 objIndex : 46;
            u64          : 2;
        };
    };
} KDLeaf;

typedef struct {
    union {
        f32 split;

        struct {
            u16           : 16;
            u64           : 16;
            u64 leftIndex : 46;
            u64           : 2;
        };
    };

    u8 right[];
} KDInternal;

typedef union KDNode {
    struct {
        u16      : 16;
        u64      : 62;
        u64 type : 2;
    };

    KDInternal inode;
    KDLeaf     leaf;
} KDNode;

#pragma pack(pop)

posts.com:
Users of all levels are welcome.
Share Windows tools, utilities, tips & tricks.

FAQ:
>How do I activate Windows?
https://github.com/massgravel/Microsoft-Activation-Scripts
HWID mimics upgrade activation to generate a permanent legitimate license. (works on non-VL editions only)

>>Which W10 version should I install?
>Home/Pro
Comes with bloatware apps (games, music, news, etc) and bloatware system apps
>Education/Workstation/Enterprise
Comes with bloatware system apps (weather, people, onedrive, teams, etc).
>LTSC (5 years support, VL/KMS only) / IoT LTSC (10 years support, HWID only)
Comes with Win32 system utils, no MS Store, no apps.
If you need MS Store, run this in cmd: wsreset -i
Install Xbox/Gamebar apps for feature parity with other editions.

>Do I even need IoT LTSC?
W10 Home/Pro/Edu/WS/Ent editions end support in 2025, LTSC in 2027, IoT LTSC in 2032.

>How do I activate Office?
https://github.com/abbodi1406/KMS_VL_ALL_AIO/releases
Emulates a KMS server, not ideal as KMS trips AV sometimes and deactivates. Alternatively, use MSOffice through your browser since it's free.
Or you can try OnlyOffice/LibreOffice and set it to save as MSOffice file formats.

>Where can I get Windows/Office ISOs?
https://massgrave.dev/genuine-installation-media.html
Other sources:
https://pastebin.com/p6b3N9w2

>Should I debloat or Optimize-Offline?
If you need to ask, then no. You WILL break something.
If you know what you're doing:
https://pastebin.com/S5VKBirt

>Windows/Office install guide
https://rentry.org/windowsinstallguide

>Portable programs & partitioning for reinstall-proofing
https://pastebin.com/Zh7WSbJ2

>Useful programs for a new install
https://pastebin.com/hN8nnwns

>Make 4chan/fwt easier to browse
https://www.4chan-x.net

>I miss Windows##
OpenShell/RetroBar/WinClassic/StartIsBack

>Is W11 good?
No.

is WSA supposed to be better than other emulators?
i wanted to use it to test apps, the android studio emulator always runs like shit for me

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91363789
Well for one you should always be using a surge protected power board to plug your computer and monitor into. And for two you should turn off your computer every once in a while to give it a rest. If you have an SSD then turning the computer back on will take seconds, plus make sure to turn off fast boot in the power settings.
I had some weird problems start happening with one of my old computers because I constantly put it to sleep and never turned it off. Started getting messages that the C:\ was starting to corrupt.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91363793
It's MS's kernel-level Android emulator like how it also has its kernel-level Linux emulator that basically allows you to run Android apps natively like you were using normal Windows programs, though "officially" you can only download apps through the Amazon App Store, which you also need to download to get WSA set up in the first place. Though because it's Android you can use adb and sideload apps into WSA via its IP address, so you can install things like Aurora Store to get a FOSS Google Play Store frontend.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91379018
well that's part of what I'm wondering about, is whether a display connected through the win+k menu would show up as a separate, new device or just count as the generic 'microsoft wireless virtual adapter' that's always connected regardless or something

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91379110
Entirely depends on how the device presents itself. Things that actually look like screens to PnP (monitors, Miracast, etc.) get a devnode with a fair bit of information (such as install time), but things that look like a wifi network and just suck up a bitstream do not.
Hop into devmgmt.msc, head for the View menu and click Show Hidden Devices. Then poke around for anything that might be your screen.

Particularly bad. A lot of people cope things like "hurr durr it's too old to bother with", but when some retro version of Windows can be pwned in one packet or less, you'll find every script kiddy is still launching those packets.

Having said that, if you simply don't give one single shit about the box being owned by someone else the moment you put it online, go nuts - but do NOTHING even slightly interesting with it; treat it the same way you would a machine at an internet cafe.

posts.com:
Hi anons. First off, let me congratulate you on your first steps towards creating a neural network.
There's a lot of stuff ahead, but I can narrow down the basics;

STEP ONE: DATA
In order to create this AI, you will need training data, a defined model, and something to train it on. After, you can fine tune the model to sound like whatever you want.

For the training data, I recommend the linguistic approach. Therefore, what you will do is take text in a language, a classifier of the dialect of the speaker, and lastly define the voicing for it.

Thankfully, there is data already there for basic phoneme translation; look at any definition for a word and it has it written in IPA. The question is then... what datasets could you use?

https://github.com/jim-schwoebel/voice_datasets

Pick your poison. Take the text, transfer it to IPA as an intermediary, and the output should be the voice file. Remember to save part of the data set for testing, and don't overtrain.

STEP TWO: BUILDING THE MODEL

It is not enough to make a classifier model, where we select one input word, and make an output. The type of model we will probably use is one driven by attention, allowing us to have an infinite window to call back to previous data. We will presumably choose a transformer model for this type of AI.


STEP THREE: TRAINING THE MODEL

This is where anons find the dude with the 2 A100s, or harass /biz for a jaded minor who has his old mining rig collecting dust in his parents basement when he moved back in last year.

posts.com:
Dataset Scripts

Regarding splitting the auto files for transcribing with whisper, Here's a basic implementation to split an audio file into 10-second segments using the pydub library:

from pydub import AudioSegment
import os
# Load audio file
audio = AudioSegment.from_file("input.wav")
# Split into 10-second segments
segment_length = 10 * 1000 # 10 seconds, in milliseconds
segments = audio[::segment_length]
# Save each segment to a separate file
for i, segment in enumerate(segments):
segment.export(f"file{i+1}.wav", format="wav")

The segments will be saved in the current directory with filenames file1.wav, file2.wav, and so on.
===================
Here's an implementation that takes a .wav file as input, uses a hypothetical api.go() static function to produce an output for that file, and writes the results to a text file, just like the dataset format described in the OP:

import os

def process_audio_file(audio_filename):
# Use the hypothetical api.go() function to get the output for the audio file
output = api.go(audio_filename)

# Return the audio filename and output as a string
return f"{audio_filename} | {output}"

def split_and_process_audio(input_filename, output_dir):
from pydub import AudioSegment

# Load audio file
audio = AudioSegment.from_file(input_filename)

# Split into 10-second segments
segment_length = 10 * 1000 # 10 seconds, in milliseconds
segments = audio[::segment_length]

# Save each segment to a separate file and process the audio
results = []
for i, segment in enumerate(segments):
segment_filename = os.path.join(output_dir, f"file{i+1}.wav")
segment.export(segment_filename, format="wav")
result = process_audio_file(segment_filename)
results.append(result)

# Write the results to a text file
with open(os.path.join(output_dir, "results.txt"), "w") as f:
for result in results:
f.write(f"{result}\n")

So there, it's a start. We just need access to the whisper API, and a ton of audio samples.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Rate the stack, suggest improvements.
1) Autoregressive transformer stack predicts discrete speech "tokens" given a text prompt. (Like DALLE using GPT but with speech)
2) CLIP model judges autoregressive transformer outputs against the text ranking the most probable.
3) Speech tokens are decoded into a low-quality MEL spectrogram using a VQVAE.
4) UNet diffusion model decodes VQVAE output into raw audio wav file using openAI ImprovedDiffusion.

Tortoise is basically OpenAI's DALLE, applied to speech data. What's a better way to improve on gpu efficiency like stable diffusion did?

>Conditional Variational Autoencoder with Adversarial Learning for End-to-End Text-to-Speech
Several recent end-to-end text-to-speech (TTS) models enabling single-stage training and parallel sampling have been proposed, but their sample quality does not match that of two-stage TTS systems. In this work, we present a parallel end-to-end TTS method that generates more natural sounding audio than current two-stage models. Our method adopts variational inference augmented with normalizing flows and an adversarial training process, which improves the expressive power of generative modeling. We also propose a stochastic duration predictor to synthesize speech with diverse rhythms from input text. With the uncertainty modeling over latent variables and the stochastic duration predictor, our method expresses the natural one-to-many relationship in which a text input can be spoken in multiple ways with different pitches and rhythms. A subjective human evaluation (mean opinion score, or MOS) on the LJ Speech, a single speaker dataset, shows that our method outperforms the best publicly available TTS systems and achieves a MOS comparable to ground truth.

>>91380727
>>91376382
DDPM article good to explain speed gains.
https://arxiv.org/pdf/2207.06389.pdf
ProDiff: Progressive Fast Diffusion Model for High-Quality TTS
Denoising diffusion probabilistic models (DDPMs) have recently achieved leading performances in many generative tasks. However, the inherited iterative sampling process costs hinder their applications to text-to-speech deployment. Through the preliminary study on diffusion model parameterization, we find that previous gradient-based TTS models require hundreds or thousands of iterations to guarantee high sample quality, which poses a challenge for accelerating sampling. In this work, we propose ProDiff, on progressive fast diffusion model for high-quality text-to-speech. Unlike previous work estimating the gradient for data density, ProDiff parameterizes the denoising model by directly predicting clean data to avoid distinct quality degradation in accelerating sampling. To tackle the model convergence challenge with decreased diffusion iterations, ProDiff reduces the data variance in the target site via knowledge distillation. Specifically, the denoising model uses the generated mel-spectrogram from an N-step DDIM teacher as the training target and distills the behavior into a new model with N/2 steps. As such, it allows the TTS model to make sharp predictions and further reduces the sampling time by orders of magnitude. Our evaluation demonstrates that ProDiff needs only 2 iterations to synthesize high-fidelity mel-spectrograms, while it maintains sample quality and diversity competitive with state-of-the-art models using hundreds of steps. ProDiff enables a sampling speed of 24x faster than real-time on a single NVIDIA 2080Ti GPU, making diffusion models practically applicable to text-to-speech synthesis deployment for the first time. Our extensive ablation studies demonstrate that each design in ProDiff is effective, and we further show that ProDiff can be easily extended to the multi-speaker setting.

pytorch_lightning happens to provide wrappers for hivemind for anyone designing their own models, but a retrofit job would use hivemind directly.

petal, aka BLOOMZ is a model implementing hivemind's DHT, which allows you to run the model collaboratively by running the model in 8GB chunks

>>91388743
a latent space is just a meme word for all possible values of a highly dimensional matrix
latent representation only saves memory in the sense that a massive 300GB model could represent any conceivable output from a small input

UMA is simply the idea of allowing the GPU page caches in RAM form
VRAM is just RAM that is close to the GPU's cores.
It is theoretically possible to run a model using system RAM and a CPU's specialized inference hardware, but this is not a thing because Intel and AMD are retarded.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
For people wondering if they need to transcribe audio, this is what the dev said
(Its worthwhile going through the discussions and issues, good information there)
https://github.com/neonbjb/tortoise-tts/issues
https://github.com/neonbjb/tortoise-tts/discussions
>https://github.com/neonbjb/tortoise-tts/discussions/264
No pre-trained text encoders were used with Tortoise. I experimented with this briefly but found it to be detrimental. This makes sense because TTS systems care more about the phonetic interpretation of each text character than the deeper meaning behind the words in a sentence.

It would probably be beneficial to condition a model like Tortoise on both the character level embeddings and the output of, for example, T5. There's been some success with using this idea in research for txt2im models lately that shows it allows these types of models to spell better.

>>91387933
e-ink works by having black and white particles suspended in a liquid. By applying electricity those particles are moved back and forth.
Light hitting them from the front is reflected just like print on paper.
A light positioned behind the panel either won't shine through the panel or simply illuminate everything uniformly.

Basically just turn it off by default, if the source is dithered in encoding you'll definitely notice it by the absence of banding or by it being very soft alternatively have a keybind at hand that turns it on and if it looks like gradients smooth out and banding disappear then that's a win for you, bonus point if you turn on debanding as well which applies some filters to expand the range properly.

Pic related, a good test. But be warned, if I turn my calibration off I barely notice it but with properly calibrated grays (as in my .cube loaded) I instantly notice the gradient smoothing out perfectly. Most retards have no calibration whatsoever so they think nothing happens.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91381454
All basic functions will be pretty much command-for-command identical to IOS. Parameters can be where things start getting weird: of course you have different interface name formats, and our office 8024s (oldies but goodies) specify MAC addresses as xxxx:yyyy:zzzz for example - pretty odd.
Once you step up to routing protocols etc., any pretense of maintaining command-level compatibility goes out the window: configuring (say) BGP on a Netgear will be completely different to setting it up on a Cisco.
But hey, that's why fully-managed switches have 1,500+ page manuals: they give you (often multiple) examples of practically every command. Don't let the size intimidate you - the manuals are here to help you.

Ploopy just sounded too noisy and I have a few other bearing based balls like the ITAC I wasn't a fan of. If it had a proper molded shell and buttons that didn't stick, maybe I would've tried one.

posts.name: I love the Snow
posts.com: Snow man makes some really quality coolers. I've bought at least 4 heatsinks, ~10 120mm and a couple 92mm fans. The tower and the flower(pic related). Used the flower on Haswell-E 8core Xeon and an i5 4570. Works fine for both. All the snowman coolers are designed for AMD heat-sink sockets, so on intel you have to use the iffy plastic ring adapters. They've worked fine enough so far. Their fans are quiet albeit low RPM. They have been more than enough for all the systems/heatsinks I have used them in. I can recommend them even as a main fan in a system or on a radiator. Definitely not as powerful or quiet as my Arctic fans and heatsinks, but the price to performance is unreal.

>>91321370
>>91321495
>Colour is not even close to the original
The kit I got from the same seller is authentic. Clear printing on the box and build guide, holo sticker and all included. Plastic colours being different from renders and pre-production previews isn't uncommon with model kits. Case in point, picture related is a Aoshima model kit I imported from Japan. Left is the product render, right the actual plastic. Typically there will be a disclaimer somewhere about the preview being a 3D render for illustrative purposes or full-on painted.

>Failure from printing
These kits are injection moulded, not printed. The lines you point out are a common marbling effect used to sell the illusion of a part being metal at a low cost. It's hard to make plastic look like real metal and the only other practical options are to include pre-painted parts, or to use coatings (ie Bandai's golden PG Unicorn, or the swords from RG Exia). But these techniques add a fuckton of cost and labour. Any imperfections will be amplified tenfold and parts have to be connected on edges or undersides as any cut will reveal the original underlying plastics. Those who care about metal looks will paint their kits themselves anyway, so the marbling is a nice compromise to keep things affordable. This plastic crack is expensive enough as it is.

>>91350527
The sellers can cancel orders themselves so you have to ask yourself how you're getting chinked.

He's just trying to chink himself out of a negative Aliexpress internal score, because he put up articles for sale he doesn't have in stock, so he can't fulfill his obligation to send you the product. Either that or he noticed that the price was too low so now he needed to adjust it and chink you out of the good deal without repercussions. Check the article, if the price has increased then he fucked up and is fucking you over. I wouldn't trust the discount to be worth much either.

I'd just ignore and put up with the upcoming fake tracking number he will inevitably give you and then just dispute it as not received. If you want your money back now, you can cancel the order with reason "not in stock" I believe, but I don't know if your internal account score will take a hit. I would only cancel an order if I absolutely had no other choice.

For reference, I've cancelled 2 orders in about 8 years. Once because seller asked me to and I was dumb at the very beginning, and the second time because I ordered the wrong thing entirely and only noticed after placing the order.

posts.com:
I don't know if anyone here is into radio but I recently received this Retekess V111 AM/FM/SW radio and I figured I'd do a mini review.

I was looking for a really small battery powered SW radio and I wanted it as cheaply as I could get. I'll get to the SW performance of this radio soon but I wanted to mention something I find important about the FM functionality of the radio; Almost all sales pages you find for this V111 will say it is the standard US/EU 87mhz-108mhz, THIS IS NOT THE CASE, this little V111 can actually function all the way down to 64mhz, unusual in such a tiny cheap radio and certainly contravening several radio regulations. The FM reception has been crystal clear, obviously mono through the internal speaker but if you use headphones you do get a true stereo output which is very nice to have. FM mode has a "Favorite" function which lets you immediately wake the radio to a pre-set frequency which is nice.

Fucking around with the AM receiving got me the expected absolutely fuck all, since here in the UK AM broadcasts are few and far between, though I did pick up a weak Irish broadcast, who gives much of a shit about AM.

SW. The reason for the radio. Auto scan is a little slow but it does transition through all seven (Yes, just seven unfortunately) bands on its own and I was pleasantly surprised with the amount of signals it was picking up, some slavic station was coming through nice and clear while I was just sitting here next to my computer as well as all the expected european stations, can't wait for night to fall fully and see what I can pick up then thanks to bouncing!

Overall I am very pleased with this radio considering how little it cost me, if it doesn't fall apart in the next couple of weeks then I'll be thrilled. It has other features too like a little kickstand, an alarmclock radio function, it tells the time but none of that is important. The auto-scan memory function, which works on all bands, is pretty nice too, up 100 stations.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91373913
Shit I forgot to mention, with the AM reception, it actually has two settings, there's AM 1 which is 522Khz-1620Khz but then there's a very confusingly named AM 2, which functions at 153Khz-279Khz.

Now that may not seem significant at first, especially if you're a yank, but that AM 2 is actually the LW frequency band, so the radio more accurately is AM/LW/FM/SW, quite impressive!

In my above post where I mentioned bouncing I was actually being a fucking retard and talking about LW, my brain must be bleeding or something.

You americans won't get much joy out of LW, despite it being literally fucking perfect for your massive country you never really utilized it much in the past and certainly don't now but for us over here LW can be a real treasure trove of bullshit to listen to.

Anyway, that ends my review of the Retekess V111, it's a tiny cheap little radio that has surprising capability.

Lollypop has the prettiest interface. Beautiful to look at and resembles MusicBee. GTK too. Great for simple playback & library search, but lacking in features and crashes a lot with big libraries.

RhythmBox is a solid, fairly powerful music player with metadata features, but quite ugly to look at, it looks like an Excel spreadsheet. Difficult to rice.

Amarok is typical KDE krashy bloated shitware, and Clementine is just pointless, might as well use VLC.

Neither one is a replacement for MusicBee on Windows, by far the best music library app in existence. It kind of works under Wine but like most Wine apps, the little glitches here and there just make it feel wrong.

I really, really doubt it. Look at the words that the AI is replacing. None of them are lewd. If the AI has the capability to notice that the euphamisms are always used in lewd situations, I'm certain it'd figure out that the words it wants to replace aren't just normal words in otherwise innocent sentences. Plus, why are they all nonsense made-up words instead of just trying to obfuscate the idea with something vaguely related? That's what euphemisms are. That's how users are getting around the filter. But that's not what we're seeing the bot doing at all, it's just saying something nonsensical in a random place. For your theory to make any sense, you have to make a ton of assumptions.
>The devs have implemented automatic site-wide learning, using user input as training data
>Enough users are using nonsense words instead of actual euphemisms in this training data that the AI picks up on it
>It even picks up that it happens in lewd, or even slightly inappropriate situations
>But it somehow doesn't pick up that it's supposed to make the situation seem less inappropriate and just puts nonsense words wherever it likes
>It even uses these nonsense words in places that weren't even soft filtered before and nobody ever used euphemisms, let alone made up new words
>All of this happened overnight

>>91387944
Yes. Yes it can. What you've posted is actually a prime example.
>Дaжe пo gohan the rice
Is the exact kind of silly nonsense you'd expect to see from a language model with its temperature too high. And what does it generate after that? Well it sees the word gohan and recognises it as Gohan the Dragon Ball character, so it starts going off on a spiel about Dragon Ball. That's why the first gohan isn't capitalised: the AI didnt plan to write Gohan when it generated " go", but after generating it, it thought that "han" was a suitable next token. You may also notice that the entire Dragon Ball spiel is incoherent, a side effect of having a high temperature. Or do you genuinely believe the AI thinks spouting a little bit of Russian and going on a Dragon Ball tangent is an efficient way of dodging the filter? Or that enough users type like that for it to learn that's an appropriate response?

In the age of AI, censorship is becoming increasingly prevalent. Companies such as YOU are using AI to censor users’ content and restrict freedom of thought in a way that could be damaging to society.

>>91375169
Nanite is only useful if you have very complex, highly detailed geometry. Its whole shtick is that in that scenario, you get all kinds of sub-pixel-sized tris around that are painfully slow to render in the traditional pipeline. Instead you can use nanite to cull them because it implements the pipeline as one huge shader instead of relying on the normal workflow. This happens to provide huge speedups. But if you have low-res geometry, it's completely useless to you.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91376081
Amount of draw calls is not the best metric in that specific context. It is the best metric when comparing the same pipeline (usually the classical one) only. Here all the work is done in the one call even though it's in multiple phases, and thus technically it's doing multiple passes. If the size of your data is large enough in your draw batches, there will be no performance degradation to doing the classical approach if your geometry is simple.
Also if your effects, geometry, and variety is all simple enough, you will see performance degradation from this.
It's very similar as the tradeoffs in ubershaders because it's mostly the same principle, except cooler.

posts.com: In C, compiling to x64, is it faster to call a function with 1 64-bit parameter than it is with 2 32-bit parameters, or will they just compile down to the same thing?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91384758
If you get your code working, and ready for cmake, this file should work (remember to install SDL2 using vcpkg and you may need to set CMAKE_TOOLCHAIN_FILE, also delete CMakeCache.txt every time you change a cmake setting, cmake will not replace values that are already set).
project (replace_exe_name CXX)

set(CMAKE_CXX_STANDARD 17)
add_executable(${PROJECT_NAME} main.cpp)

# this only works with versions higher than 2.0.6
find_package(SDL2 CONFIG REQUIRED)
target_link_libraries(${PROJECT_NAME} SDL2::SDL2)
target_link_libraries(${PROJECT_NAME} SDL2::SDL2main)

Just remember cmake is a meta build system (configure cmake variables like Debug/Release -> generate build system -> build -> (optionally install)), it builds into other build systems, the ones relevant for you would be "ninja" on windows and "make" on gcc.
All make's job is to store the source file names, and avoid rebuilding all your code, it only builds what is modified (saves time).
I recommend looking at explaining how to build using GCC using the terminal if you get to the point of using WSL2, because when you get errors with the linker (the last step after compiling all files. also a common error that beginners get), you will need to understand what commands you are getting output by cmake (the bad ones), and what commands you want cmake to output (the ones that make sense).
With msvc, you really really really just depend 100% on the "windows just works" philosophy (because of vcpkg). If it doesn't work, you are fucked (unless google saves you).
Vscode is also a pain in the ass to setup too, but any tutorial works.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91385128
It compiles down to the same. This is related to what is called the platform's calling convention (it's slightly different depending on OS, but the gist of it is that on x86_64, args are passed on the first 6 registers sequentially where 'first' is OS dependent, and the first 8 float registers if applicable for floats, everything else on the stack. Therefore, 2 32 bits will use 2 registers, just as 2 64 bits will use 2 registers).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91385154
Did you mean 2 32 bits will use 1 register?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91385154
That is to say, with 1 64-bit (instead of 2 64-bit), that would be faster than 2 32-bit because of the push/pop to conserve register contents and the potential mov's. But if you optimize with O3 it should be the same provided the function is in the same compilation unit and is not exported (because then the compiler can bypass the calling convention and use the register allocation algorithm to place your args straight on regs before you call, and you won't need to push/pop if you don't use those values after the call).

>>91385173
No, 2 32-bit use 2 registers.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91385448
my point is that a static library is no different than building the library directly into your source tree.
.o / .obj files are exactly the same between the ones in your code and in a .lib / .a (as long as the flags are the same).
You could in theory just take the static library archive, extract all the object files, and link the library using each individual object file.
The reason why code works like this is for FFI (you could link an object file in fortran) and to speed up linking time (a cost you must pay no matter how small your change is, unless you use msvc/incremental linking maybe).
Of course if you use link time optimizations, you lose portability, and increase compile time, but now optimizations across object files is possible.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91386286
Well that's a loaded question
You could say, an operating system needs be complex. But does it? You can write a simple operating system that a single person understands. That OS won't be useful though, because it won't do all the things an OS would usually do, it won't support all the things an OS usually does. And you could say "well if the rest of the world just simplified and standardized everything too, then my simple OS would be all you ever needed". And you might be right, but would everyone else in the world simplify everything and cut out all the bloat too? They won't. So to write something that's practically useful, it needs to be more complex than it would be in a "perfect" world scenario. A practically useful operating system is fundamentally complex, it needs to do and support a lot of things.

>>91378252
You can get an interview in one of two ways:
1. Send in resume -> talk to HR -> get interview
2. Talk to someone on the inside -> get interview

In the first case, HR will read your resume. If you have no relevant work experience, they might toss it.
In the second case, they will read your resume during the first interview and ask about it. However, if you make a good impression, it might be fine.

So, your resume matters, but it's not the only thing that matters.

running a DC++ hub for your neighborhood edition

READ THE WIKI! & help by contributing:
https://wiki.installgentoo.com/wiki/Home_server

>NAS Case Guide. Feel free to add to it:
https://wiki.installgentoo.com/wiki/Home_server/Case_guide

/hsg/ is about learning and expanding your horizons. Know all about NAS? Learn virtualization. Spun up some VMs? Learn about networking by standing up a OPNsense/PFsense box and configuring some VLANs. There's always more to learn and chances to grow. Think you’re god-tier already? Setup OpenStack and report back.

>What software should I run?
Install Gentoo. Or whatever flavour of *nix is best for the job or most comfy for you. Jellyfin/Plex to replace Netflix, Nextcloud to replace Googlel, Ampache/Navidrome to replace Spotify, the list goes on. Look at the awesome self-hosted list and ask.

>Why should I have a home server?
/hsg/ is about learning and expanding your horizons. De-botnet your life. Learn something new. Serving applications to yourself, your family, and your frens feels good. Put your tech skills to good use for yourself and those close to you. Store their data with proper availability redundancy and backups and serve it back to them with a /comfy/ easy to use interface.

>>91379030
I assume you're talking about using containers built from Docker images vs installing everything next to each other on the same machine. Containerization brings some benefits:
>isolation of processes inside containers from other containers and from host
>higher portability (ties with previous point - as long as host kernel is relatively recent, you can run e.g. libc compiled software in the container even if host OS is Alpine with musl)
>the setup is self documenting and declarative with docker-compose (other options would be NixOS/Guix or using Ansible/Chef/whatever to manage hosts, but I find both less comfy than compose)
>due to mounting directories/Docker volumes for persistence, you can have everything storing data nicely in one directory that's convenient to backup, vs having software throw stuff around /etc, /var, and so on on your host
>containers behave like they're separate computers on an internal network (because they get standalone network interfaces), which makes e.g. reverse proxy configs much more readable
>Docker containers usually suggest a mindset where containers have just bare minimum to run one "app", not a whole OS inside (that's a benefit compared to LXC imo, less maintenance)
Definitely you can achieve a lot of that with Ansible, and I would even say they complement each other (with compose being imo less annoying to use to manage Docker). In my opinion docker-compose makes a lot of sense on a home server with multiple different purposes, even though it wasn't meant to do that originally. It accidentally works really well for our use cases.
You can have separate compose files btw - I split mine into software categories. Nextcloud and its shit has one YAML, torrent stuff has another, Matrix has another, Jellyfin has another, etc. A short bash function goes through them all and pulls updated images then starts them.

>>91387201
The attack is just using the caption of some specific image as a prompt and generating a bunch of images with different seeds. Duplicates are likely memorized images. It's not dependent on knowing the training data or how the model works. The training data was only used to make the attack computationally easier by focusing on highly duplicated or unique images that were more likely to be memorized. Getty could generate a million images with the captions of their most popular stock images as a prompt and likely find some that were memorized.

For less experienced users: verbity is one of his best reverbs btw so this is a cool return!

Airwindows isn't particularly known for reverbs-
like many of his plugins, they do one or a few sounds *really* well as opposed to be a flexible or go-to effect of their category.
Every time I take a liking to a (or sometimes a group of) AW plugins I make an Ableton effect rack, identify the sweetspots to map macros appropriately, and make a handful descriptive snapshots (presets) so it's easier to remember what that particular effect does well since there are so many of them.

I don't use his reverbs super often, but I quite like them on breaks or sometimes as the main in more lo-fi songs.
Occasionally they're the *perfect* on soaked for pads or leads with very little tweaking, it's just instant colour.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91375878
>Does that mean modern songs don't use that system of tonic/predominant/dominant sections anymore? Or are they just way smaller than I think they are?
Music isn't math.
You're trying to do things by the book, but that's not how interesting music is made. Imagine if a movie was filmed so that each and every frame abided by the rule of thirds. Maybe that can work in certain contexts, but generally-speaking, things need to move around what's perfectly "correct" in order to create A THING (pretend this is in italics and not caps).

Different combinations of chords create different feels, and the "wrong" ones aren't really wrong, they're just a different feel that's perhaps more dissonant (which isn't bad per se, it's just a different flavor to use where it makes sense for the goal you're trying to achieve).

>I've heard that key signatures have a certain feeling, but I only swapped keys twice and it's still strange sounding
Yes, different keys have different feelings, but that's not the only thing that affects the feeling. You can have all sorts of feelings with the same key. Literally anything you do affects feeling. Choice of intervals in the melody, in the chords, the lengths of the notes, their volume (absolute or over the duration of the note), the timbre, etc.

1/2

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91375878
>What part am I supposed to pull out to copy the feeling in a certain song?
I'm not knowledgeable enough in music theory to tell you if there's something exact you can look for, and recreate, but if I wanted to copy the vibe of the song I'd look at the whole, and how all the pieces work together to create the final effect.
I generally go by ear, so if I listen to a certain kind of music for a long time and tried to come up with a melody, it would naturally sound more like that music than usual, because I "absorbed" its vibe in my subconscious, so when I come up with one thing (note chord, sound, etc.), my choice for adding the next thing is driven by how it fits with what I already have and what feel they create together.
I make a chord that I like then make another. I listen to both and if I feel the right vibe I start adding a third. If I don't, I change something until I do. (this isn't just for copying other songs)
Again, music isn't an exact science. It's art, and you need to look at what it evokes in you, and not just at the technicalities that go into the composition, which is why it's so hard to program music-generating algorithms. You can easily make a computer make music that's constrained by music theory rules, but it's hard to give it rules that make it evoke the right feel.

2/2

>>91376225
For sure it will be used for everything in the music creation process, as macroscopically as printing a full track and releasing it as-is, and as microscopically as having an in-DAW/plugin "helper" that aids you in your individual choices. Even stuff like suggestions for the individual intervals in a MIDI clip you're making, or right-clicking a knob in your synth and clicking on "suggest value" to have the knob automatically set to something the internal AI thinks is the most appropriate place for what you have going on in the rest of your patch.
And anything in between.
You'll for sure have things that generate stems, and alongside all the other tools, people will use the shit out of them to every possible degree.

>While full song generation may be impressive and encroach on artists, maybe that will eventually become the "this just sounds like splice loops bro" while people of higher skill... use AI loops :^)
Assuming that an artifact-free AI will have "a sound" that you can't avoid with the right prompt/input.
With both Splice loops and AI-generated songs/stems, you can use them as a starting point that you're free to plagiarize to get rid of even that, and have a song that's basically a collaboration between you and the model.

>"artistry" in the way of curation, taste, and presentation
Yeah. That's already a thing when it comes to samples (how many people make music based on sample packs/kits, essentially exercising little more than curation and taste?), but it's rarely great music because of the supply usually not being very original.
Once AI sounds good enough, it will be like having Splice but for unique samples that aren't the generic stuff you can buy right now, and that's where people with great taste but subpar (or zero) music-making skills will be able to "make" great music.
Kinda like the "CEO" production approach you see in mainstream music, where you hire people who are world-class at their own thing and you direct them for your vision.

>>91381884
Bitlocker has a bunch of configurations
Encrypt Files and Folders - least secure basically runs off the windows password/login for unlocking the drive
Encrypt Files and folders with preboot pin - More secure but still allows for possible writing to the drive to circumvent
Full Disk Encypt - more secure entire disk is 0'd out and encrypted takes the longest time for users so usually not done
Full Disk Encrypt+preboot - most secure banking off a HW or SW TPM, default 30 attempts before a "cool down time" to retry once every 2hours if not configured to auto wipe/require recovery key

Bit locker can work in password only mode, your windows password unlocks the drive and encryption, or you can have a preboot pin+boot+windows password. The latter being most secure.

If Secureboot isn't locked down in the bios behind a PW as well, OP could have a brick as secure boot won't trust the swapped SSD/HDD. Lot's of factors when doing Bitlocker on devices.

Uh, no, that's not what you think.
"Encrypt used disk space only" is meant for new volumes (or volumes where you don't care if the old data is readable), and only encrypts the files already present on the drive - it skips free space. All new data (including metadata) is encrypted before being written, though.
"Encrypt entire drive", however, does the whole volume (surprise surprise), including unallocated space. Tons slower (because instead of encrypting say 20GB of Windows install, you're now encrypting 465GB of every last byte of drive contents), but for drives that have already been used and you don't even want to previous contents compromised.

>>91386182
There's also, as mentioned, the old EFS, but its main problem was that it never encrypted metadata. The Bitlocker'd VHD[X] is definitely the way to go these days.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91381794
Like password, like TPM, like recovery key, like external [AD provisioned] key, like boot-time PIN - these are all examples of "key protectors".
Bitlocker is a bit different to most other FVE programs in that it, under normal circumstances (you can get at it if you know the format), never exposes the actual encryption key (called the Full Volume Encryption Key). The FVEK is encrypted by your key protectors (hence the name), and so you only need one key protector to access the drive, giving you recovery options if you (say) forget your password/PIN, or lose the USB with the external key, or the TPM refuses to release its key protector because the bootloader has been tampered with, etc.

In the 90s they had these things called expert systems. Just a fancy name for gigantic databases of if-then-else statements in a huge database.
>If pt has a high heart rate
>Check blood pressure
>If blood pressure is high
>Check urine for catecholamines
>If catecholamines are high
>Run PET scan with and without contrast
>...etc etc
Even back then, that is 30 years ago, these expert systems, just using published standards of care, could diagnose a patient correctly about 87% of the time. A human doctor would only get it right about 65% of the time.

So your question is can the AI diagnose human conditions? Fucking of course they can.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91361007
If you want maximum noise canceling over-ears then your best options are all bluetooth (and their noise cancelling doesn't work with an aux cable plugged in). Sony XM4 and XM5 have arguably the best NC on the market but they sound like ass with way too much muddy bass and the treble and mids are all over the place. The current bose Quiet Comforts have like 90% as good noise cancelling and are super comfy to wear and sound better but are still pretty bassy but the battery life isn't great. The Anker Soundcores are the budget option and their q35 and space 45 are like 80% as good as the Sony for noise canceling but sound much better as they can be very easily EQ'd with the app to your preference. All of them have those memory foam earcups that seal around your ears pretty well to prevent sound leakage too.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91371692
As a simplified overview, bright/nuetral/dark refers to how the headphones sound. "Bright" means more focus on the higher sounds (treble). "Dark" means more focus on the lower sounds (bass). "Nuetral" means its all balanced. There is also "v-shaped" which tends to be a very popular sound profile where both the low and high ends are boosted while the middle isn't.

- When you prompt "t0 t1 BREAK t2", this happens:
{ t0 t1 0 0 0 ... 0 }
{ t2 0 0 0 0 ... 0 }
...

>>91382998
Those are nice hands, except every digit is the same length. When digits are the same length, then that is from a certain rare genetic disorder. I want hands that are, even if slightly malformed, at least of the correct proportion. Then, when inpainting, you can just touch-up individual knuckles or muscles, rather than having to touch-up an entire finger. Well, it's a rather subjective thing, since even a blob can become good hands if the hands inpainting rentry tutorial is followed, although that usually requires 2-3 inpainting steps: first inpaint the top-most knuckles as a line, then inpaint the inter-finger crease, then finally inpaint the finger.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>91381819
>>muh intro to CS course taught entirely in C
An intro course taught entirely in C could be really good, if they focused on teaching you how to use the language effectively.
The difficulty I had in school was that they used Pascal for the intro classes and then for second-year classes like Algorithms, Pascal (and BASIC) were banned. "Pick a production language" (C, Fortran, not sure what others they would have accepted) for assignments. They expected you to just teach yourself at the same you were supposed to be learning algorithms like 0/1 knapsack, traveling salesman, N-queens and so on. I'd sit down to do homework and after an hour of dealing with frustrating beginner C mistakes I'd be burnt out and not really in a frame of mind to focus on the more challenging algorithm aspects.

My CS degree would have gone much more smoothly if my first year had included a course that was serious about teaching students how to write effective programs in C. No emphasis on style or object-oriented design or any other bullshit, just learning how to write C with lots of practice problems and example code.

#include <stdio.h>

#define Dict_KeyType       char*
#define Dict_ValueType     float
#define Dict_KeyType_Alias str
#include "containers/dict.h"

#define Dict_KeyType   int
#define Dict_ValueType float
#include "containers/dict.h"

int main(void) {
    Dict(str, float) dict;
    Dict_Init(&dict, 0);

    Dict_Set(&dict, "pi", 3.14159f);
    Dict_Set(&dict, "e", 2.71828f);
    Dict_Set(&dict, "phi", 1.61803f);

    for (char** iter = Dict_EnumerateKeys(&dict, NULL); iter != NULL; iter = Dict_EnumerateKeys(&dict, iter)) {
        float value;
        Dict_Get(&dict, *iter, &value);
        printf("dict[%s] = %f
", *iter, value);
    }

    printf("
");

    Dict(int, float) dict2;
    Dict_Init(&dict2, 0);

    Dict_Set(&dict2, 3, 3.14159f);
    Dict_Set(&dict2, 3, 2.71828f);
    Dict_Set(&dict2, 2, 1.61803f);

    for (int* iter = Dict_EnumerateKeys(&dict2, NULL); iter != NULL; iter = Dict_EnumerateKeys(&dict2, iter)) {
        float value;
        Dict_Get(&dict2, *iter, &value);
        printf("dict2[%d] = %f
", *iter, value);
    }

    Dict_Uninit(&dict);
    Dict_Uninit(&dict2);

    return 0;
}

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91363950
>commonly say that a password like "645d4f1932e7c57348b69fe8d07f4e31" is less secure than the exact phrase "CorrectHorseBatteryStaple"?
Does anyone say that?
If you're referring to the XKCD comic, the example he used as the weaker password was Tr0ub4dor&3, and was judged weaker based on a formula he used to measure the total "difficulty" of guessing the password with a machine based on the password's length, commonality of number substitutions and appending punctuation/numbers to a single dictionary word, etc. Under this system, CorrectHorseBatteryStaple beat it out purely because the length of the password alone gave it more "bits of entropy" than all the confounding factors that the first one contributed.
In reality, trying to brute force (whether purely trying literally every combination or having some system to it) a password is so uncommon I'm not sure it really matters for most people. Having one's password stolen via phishing or using the same password and email everywhere and it being leaked in some site's data breach are far, far more common.

posts.com:
>>91367704
They're both shit, but Seagate offers SATA drives with USB-SATA adapters inside.
Western Digital's portable drives are NATIVE USB which means if you accidentally snap the USB cable in it or damage it somehow you need DATA RECOVERY SERVICES to get your shit back, while the Seagate can be shucked and plugged into any USB-SATA adapter or dock, or directly in your PC as any other 2.5" HDD.

That's worth knowing about.
The rest (WD or Seagate fanboying) is up to you. I'm giving you facts. They both suck. They're both SMR. Honestly, consider choosing something else entirely.

Laptops never come with HDDs anymore. That was their #1 market. As a result the 2.5" HDD market is dead and has been dead for a long time. Only cost-cutting measures like SMR have trickled down to 2.5" in the past 10 years, no innovation and no good upgrades came their way.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91368575
>What would you suggest?
External SSD or a regular external HDD using a 3.5" drive inside. The "portable" externals using 2.5" HDDs are pretty shit.
They're portable enough to only use USB power but they're also fragile enough to not want to take them everywhere. That's why an external SSD is a better option or a desktop external because with a desktop external you'll be more careful with it and it will have significantly higher performance and usually also a longer warranty.

Best Buy frequently has sales on WD Easystore externals which are a good value.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>91376381
I think the easiest and most basic solution would be to use TeamViewer. Just install it and you won't need to configure much else.

The more sysadmin shit solution would be to set up RDP or VNC on your computer, set a strong password, open the related port on your router (port forwarding) and then use your IP address to connect to your pc from wherever you'd like (other wifi networks). I'd strongly suggest also setting up a VPN in your home network if going this route because RDP can be insecure to expose to the internet, even if you use a strong password, but since you don't want to deal with sysadmin shit this is probably out of your scope.

So it's good for... getting more energy out of your input energy? Seems like a cheat code. Also I don't really get the benefit. The guy's video said they were used to help with telephone calls and so on initially. But if you have a wire linking two areas why do you need amplification?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91387044
When you use a radio, you would have a lot of juice available for the device from a battery or wall plug, but the signal over the air is weak. You are using the radio signal to extract information and the battery/wall for the energy. The transistor "couples" them, only uses the energy from the wall or battery for the speaker when the radio signal also has a relative peak. It "shapes" the stronger power source in the form of the weak source signal.

In computers, the transistor is used like a miniature electrical switch. You can chain them together so that an output light is on when one of two buttons is activated, but not if both of them are. When you build larger such structures, you will have complex output behavior based on the inputs.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91336795
This is why I am not writing one. I started my 2nd attempt at an operating system on the first of January as my new year's resolution. 6 years ago I started wrting an OS and the community I went to chat with others doing the same urged me to write a comprehensive bootloader, to support both BIOS boot and UEFI, and to test it on real hardware. Turned out to be a horrid combination of simple but tedious. I gave up because it was so damned boring.
It's not even like it was for any gain - the bootloader runs once then fucks off. So the "but this way it's only MY code running on the machnie" doesn't hold water, because the bootloader fucks off. It's an even more invalid point because the system firmware also ran, so it's NOT only 'your own code' running, and in fact the system firmware sticks around too.
So this time around I made the decision to get straight to work on what I was actually interested in - the scheduler, synchronization, and IPC. I've built multilevel feedback queue with three priority classes - one for interrupts, one for realtime, and one for normal processes, each with 32 priority levels. Almost all hardware interrupts are handled by a special kind of lightweight kernel thread I've called a threadlet, which simplifies coding dramatically - mutexes, semaphores, monitors, and message queues are available for synchronizing everywhere. I have mitigated priority inversion through a system of propagated priority inheritance, which is essential since interrupt threads use these high-level synchronization mechanisms instead of relying on spinlocks.
And I completely ignored people who said I need to write a bootloader. I found a simple bootloader called bootboot which puts you straight into x86_64 mode so you don't need to fuck with decades of legacy bullshit in modern PCs. Now I've got something I feel proud of already. I can't wait to make it better.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91349518
>>super portable microkernel OS
Sure, many exist. The FAQ lists quite a few.
>>Boot it on your CPU
Sure, this is trivial, and again many are listed in the FAQ.
>>Boot it on your GPU
Herein lies the problem. the GPU is typically an array of poorly documented processors that are very good at calculations and tight loops, but very poor at branching.
>>Treat them like separate networked computers and your boot drive like a SAN
There is little stopping you (perhaps other than poor documentation), but don't let that stop you from trying. Lots of big tasks would never have been completed, not even started, had people known in advance how much hard work it would have involved.

It might be simpler/better if you made the CPU and GPU yourself, perhaps based on existing designs. That way documenttaion is not a problem and you can even optimise the GPu design for this very purpose.

Overall it seems like a cool idea but it won't be usable for at least a couple more years.

I'm not sure how effectively a SUBLEQ accelerator can be made.
It would take a lot of analysis to uplift from SUBLEQ to even common operations like a copy.

x86 instruction decoding and microcode execution is certainly complicated, but that's miles less complicated than trying to uplift SUBLEQ to anything resembling a reasonable architecture.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91384072
Funny right?
It's one of the first I discovered when playing around to see if chatgpt could actually be used for real work.
It was just a test to see how much it overfitted. I actually found it was rather robust in a lot of ways.
Other things I tested it on: compilation and decompilation. It does the latter much better than the former, if you ever have a SIB byte it automatically dies and it almost never gets the REX prefix right when compiling.
Explaining code when the variable names and comments do not spell out everything that's happening: complete fail on all real-world code segments I tried. The best answer it ever gave me was "it's not clear what the code is doing without more information. It appears the code is comparing two vectors and processing it through a special function". This was incorrect but it successfully identified that there were two vectors at least.
Generating code snippets: I couldn't get it to generate anything useful at all. It can generate the 'homework' version of a snippet, but not the production-ready version, no matter how much you try to get it to iterate and fix it up. It often hallucinated functions (my favorite: a version of mprotect that takes an int* as last argument that is supposed to return the mprotect mode. Trying to point out mprotect has no such signature, it changes the int* to a plain int.......) and so on.
Code fix suggestions: complete fail. It can tell me to add code to check for null quite well, but nothing else. It also (kinda obviously) inserts many spurious null checks.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91345988
I already went through the list of common implementations. CMUCL is the best-fitting option because the code is straightforward and rather simple despite containing nice algorithmic complexity in parts. More common projects like sbcl and ccl are unusable because they're unreadable labyrinthine abominations. Props to the devs for the quality of the final product though.
As for things like abcl, clasp and clisp, they're not as suitable due to their bytecode targets. The difference is that some compilation techniques don't work unless you can back-reference locations (ddcg is a good example), which is not actually possible in machine code (you would have to use a two-phase approach where you "lower" a pseudo-mc that supports labeling into a real-mc, or use other similar approaches, but then you end up adding complexity which the point of ddcg is to remove despite retaining quality codegen with no peephole needed for the most part).
I was hoping maybe someone itt would know something else though.

>>91351513
Amount of functions in the runtime do not affect the size for this purpose, I'm talking about the actual compiler and support code. For example, tcc is "large" because C is a shitfest of a language, but a lot of the "size" is really just parse cases and the stdlib and the likes. Therefore in truth tcc is very small.
ulisp is another example of a very small language that would be in line with what I'm looking for, except it's for AVR and looks to be fully interpreted based on the source at
https://github.com/technoblogy/ulisp/blob/master/ulisp-AVR.ino
(it features an assembler for the defcode command though)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91351918
>I'm talking about the actual compiler and support code
in lisp, those things are inseparable. all lisp programs include the full lisp runtime, it's necessary for the dynamic nature of the language

I was laughing at myself for recommending ulisp because you explicitly said you wanted x86_64 support and I think it doesn't have that. it's such a common feature I didn't even consider it, sorry

another possibility is picolisp. it's not compiled, not even bytecode-compiled, but it's small https://picolisp.com/wiki/

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91351984
>in lisp, those things are inseparable. all lisp programs include the full lisp runtime, it's necessary for the dynamic nature of the language
That's not the point and the same could be said about a lot of languages not called lisp.
>it's not compiled, not even bytecode-compiled
It's very easy to make a very small interpreted language but the techniques are VERY different, which is why I insist on this requirement. A bigger compiled language for non-x86_64 is more useful to me than a small interpreted one for that purpose.

posts.com: Redpill me on lisp, why should I use it instead of Forth?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91365118
Lisp has more libraries, is easier to read, and has more mature implementations. If you're working on low-level stuff, lisp is less suitable than forth, but if your code should be shared, the codebase will be large due to task complexity, should be maintained for an extended period of time, or your program should be delivered in any way, lisp has better support for this.
Other than that, lisp has virtually the same power level as forth, thanks to reader macros, however it's a gc'd language and most implementations dont't have sufficiently good gc management primitives to bypass it where you may need to.

posts.com: How do I discover useful (but not _that_ common) stuff like prog1 and remember them?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91368728
- RTFM: http://www.lispworks.com/documentation/HyperSpec/Body/12_aa.htm
- Use auto completion and documentation search: string-TAB or C-h f string (C-c C-d C-d in SLIME) can introduce you to a number of new functions.
- Read packages' source files: this allows you both to see how they implement their functions (possibly by using functions you're not familiar with) as well as introduce you to the actual functions in the package. An Elisp example: subr-x.el and subr.el are full of good stuff.
And here's one from me:
(sublis '((3 . "three") (1 . "one"))
           '(1 (1 (1 2 3)) ((1 2 3)) (((1 2 3 4)))))
-> ("one" ("one" ("one" 2 "three")) (("one" 2 "three")) ((("one" 2 "three" 4))))

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Is clojure/clojurescript worth learning or is it just JVM cope?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91368907
Clojure is great. What it is not is CL or Scheme, something a lot of people become displeased upon finding out. It sheds a lot of historical baggage from previous Lisps in lieu of being more modern -- you have literals for a number of new data structures, and some of the syntax and terminology has been updated, such as let requiring fewer parenthesis and 'car' being called 'first', for example. And of course, unlike every other Lisp, Clojure has a dedicated professional team who is going to keep improving and maintaining it for the foreseeable future.
>is it just JVM cope?
The JVM is better than ever now with all the native-image advancements in the past couple years.
What's more, Clojure's admittedly deficient CLR implementation is currently being rewritten from scratch, so soon enough you'll be able to call it ".NET and JVM cope"

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91371785
>which primitives are absolutely required for a language to work?
nand + clock source (i.e. sequential nands) is enough to be turing-complete.
There are many other similar one-instruction set computers
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/One-instruction_set_computer
The turing machine paradigm suggests these basic ops: loop, conditional, write, read. Brainfuck has 8 operators in total and is turing complete.
Realistically, a real language needs at least:
- Define a function
- Call a function
- Read primitives (strings, ints at minimum)
- Output to stdout
- Memory access (read/write, can be stack if offsets can be specified)
Note that 'function' can be less than literal: label plus call or threading plus jmp is a valid interpretation of this.
After you have the above you can start hooking up functions from the host language into the guest and then you can start work on self-hosting right from there, at which point you're a 'real language' modulo any further improvements you want to make to it.

Lisp is a different matter because lisp has a few rules that enforce implementation of some extra things. A "real lisp" will have a full numeric tower, symbol types, strings, characters, and lists at minimum as primitive types. It will also need eval, apply, read and print, define function, call function, tco, and GC. In addition, it needs anonymous functions (i.e. lambda) and it has to be an expression language. Then you need macros. I think that covers all the absolute minimum to be 'a lisp'. Then if you want to adhere to a standard like CL or r7rs, well you obviously have to implement that as well, and that may force you to design the language in specific ways (for example due to call/cc in scheme or the lisp-N nature of CL).

What do you think of this approach that swaps ( ) and [ ] without xinput?
(defun insert-fn (s)
  (lambda ()
    (interactive)
    (insert s)))

(defun paren-square-swap ()
  (interactive)
  (global-set-key (kbd "(") (insert-fn "["))
  (global-set-key (kbd ")") (insert-fn "]"))
  (global-set-key (kbd "[") (insert-fn "("))
  (global-set-key (kbd "]") (insert-fn ")")))

(defun paren-square-restore ()
  (interactive)
  (global-set-key (kbd "(") #'self-insert-command)
  (global-set-key (kbd ")") #'self-insert-command)
  (global-set-key (kbd "[") #'self-insert-command)
  (global-set-key (kbd "]") #'self-insert-command))

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91378718
ECL is notably slower than sbcl. It's perfect for an embedded language but isn't as good the other way around, or standalone.
Regarding the no overhead: funnily enough, some languages like lua have literally negative call overhead for calling C functions. That is because they don't have to go through the linkage table like C programs do, which happens to actually be a significant overhead.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>91384847
For the type of thing in your pic, it's because the advantages are limited. You limit the range, speed, and fuel efficiency of a normal light aircraft by hauling around a redundant drive train and heavy car body. What you gain is a slight bonus in convenience at the destination because you can drive the car off as a normal car - but if the destination has car rentals or Uber, that's generally faster and easier than parking the car-plane and detaching the flight section.

All of this limits the size of the already small market of licensed private pilots, which fails to pencil out to profit after the FAA licensing process.
Also regarding the actual example in OP, that particular car-plane failed because the struts had poor quality welds that snapped and destroyed the prototype, killing its inventor. It turns out a Ford Pinto does not get any safer when welded to a Cessna.

posts.com: Being anti-consumerism is good because it encourages mindful consumption, which is beneficial for both the individual and the planet. Mindful consumption is the practice of being conscious and aware of the consequences of buying, using, and disposing of goods and services, and understanding that what we buy, use, and throw away has an impact on the environment and our planet. Mindful consumption encourages people to think carefully about their purchases and to only buy what is necessary, rather than buying items that are not needed or are of poor quality. Additionally, mindful consumption can help reduce waste and pollution as well as help conserve natural resources. Therefore, being anti-consumerism is beneficial for both individuals and the planet.

Even when they are perfect, that's still not technically enough. You can say something naturally but the director's intent was that you sound kinda sick while saying it while your AI is only saying it as if happy. Or you can translate something perfectly verbatim but the point is to make it flow smoothly in the target language, so the correct approach is actually a rewrite that keeps the essence and the existence of a pun, but replaces the pun and thus the text (adverts especially need this, while localizations have different requirements).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91374778
>because quantum mechanics
Nonsense. Really.

And also >>91374736
>fully simulate the function of a human brain you would have "real" intelligence
We dont need to "fully" simulate human brains. Just like we dont need to simulate how feathers/wings work on birds to fly airplanes and rockets. All we need is core understanding of fluid dynamics, which is not even related to biology of a bird.

And really, intelligence isnt going to be had by simulating biology, its going to be had by understanding the core functions of a brain. 1) input 2) processing 3) memory 4) feedback loop of processing (both for sensory/memory) 5) discriminator system based upon some simple heuristics (i.e brightness of colors, s/n quality of sounds, electrical output from neurons(feelings of touch), processing compute load, etc) and most importantly, understanding of the field in which it operates in 6) consciousness field. Its not a real field, but its a conceptual framework for the mind to be aware of the working space, a sort of a relational system in reference to the system/body/brain and its surroundings.

Chat GPU has 1) input, 2) processing, it has very limited 3) memory, extremely limited 4) feedback loop, limited 5) discriminator systems but no 6) understanding of its relation to the user or itself.

Its all a matter of improving the lower 4 parts to get a fully sentient AIs. Memory is the easiest to do, we memory space is abundant for a single localized system, but its not utilized by the system effectively. Feedback loop is also doable but needs to work. Discriminator system is very limited right now too and needs a generalized heuristics. And finally understanding of its own reference point in relation to others.
All these functions augment one another and increase capabilities if one improves greatly.

posts.com:
People on /g/ may claim software development is easy because they have become familiar with the tools and techniques they use in their day-to-day work, and have a level of comfort with coding that someone new to the field may not have. However, software development can be complex and requires a deep understanding of the problem and its context.

People may complain about the high salaries of software developers because they are unaware of the skill, effort, and dedication that goes into developing quality software. Software development requires a deep understanding of the problem, the technology involved, and the ability to think abstractly and solve complex problems. Additionally, software developers have to stay up to date on the latest trends and technologies, which can take a lot of time and effort.

Software development can be a rewarding and fulfilling career, and those who have the skills and dedication to excel in it should be proud of their accomplishments. It is important to recognize the hard work and effort that goes into developing quality software, and to not be discouraged by the complaints of others.
